title: Architecture: Hybrid App Store + Direct Distribution Strategy
description:
Design VoiceFlow with modular architecture to support both App Store (lite) and direct distribution (pro) versions.

## Background
- Accessibility API (AXUIElement) required for context-aware features
- Accessibility API NOT allowed in Mac App Store sandbox
- Input Monitoring (CGEventTap) IS allowed in sandbox

## Strategy
**App Store Lite Version:**
- Basic dictation (type at cursor)
- Voice commands
- Uses Input Monitoring only

**Direct Pro Version:**
- All lite features plus:
- Context-aware punctuation (reads text field content)
- Smart terminal mode detection
- Inline text rewriting/replacement

## Implementation Notes
- Core engine should be shared between versions
- Accessibility features should be modular/optional
- Runtime detection of available permissions
- Feature flags or build configurations to differentiate

## Research Session: 2024-12-27

### Command Detection Options Evaluated

| Library | Latency | Size | Custom | License |
|---------|---------|------|--------|---------|
| Porcupine | <100ms | ~2MB | Yes | Free non-commercial |
| openWakeWord | ~80ms | ~50MB | Yes | Apache 2.0 |
| Vosk | Real-time | 50MB | Vocab | Apache 2.0 |
| Apple SpeechTranscriber | Fast | System | Built-in | Native |

### macOS 26 SpeechAnalyzer (Now Available)
- 2.2x faster than Whisper V3 Turbo
- On-device, no rate limits
- Modules: SpeechDetector, SpeechTranscriber, DictationTranscriber

### Recommended Architecture
1. Porcupine/openWakeWord for always-on wake (<4% CPU)
2. Apple SpeechTranscriber for commands
3. AssemblyAI for high-accuracy dictation

### Sources
- picovoice.ai/platform/porcupine
- github.com/dscripka/openWakeWord
- developer.apple.com/documentation/speech/speechanalyzer

title: Evaluate wake word alternatives - 'flow' is hard to recognize
description:
The 'flow' prefix commands (flow on, flow off, flow sleep) use the /f/ sound which is a weak labiodental fricative. Research indicates:

- /f/ is harder to detect than plosives (k, t, p) or sibilants (s)
- Recommended wake words have 6+ phonemes; 'flow on' only has ~5

Consider alternatives with stronger starting sounds:
- 'voice on/off/sleep' (voiced fricative, 6 phonemes)  
- 'go flow' prefix (plosive start)
- 'talk on/off/sleep' (plosive start)
- Or investigate global hotkeys as an alternative to voice commands for mode switching
